div.l: Al wer͗e he snybbed erly and late
And somtyme y ladde with reuell to Newgate
But at þe laste his maist̉er hym bethoȝht
Vp on a day when he his papir͗e soȝht
Of a ꝓprouerbe þat seith þis same worde
Wel bet is roten̄ appull oute of hoorde
Than þan it roteth alle þe remenᵃaunte
So farith it by a ryotous seruᵃaunte
It is full lasse harme to lat hym passe
Than he schende all þe seruᵃauntes in þe place
Ther for͗e his maist̉er ȝaff hym a quitaunce
And bad hym go with sorowe and myschaunce
And þus þis Ioly prentys had his leve
Nowe lete hym ryot all þe nyȝht or leue
And for þ̉er is no theef with oute a look
That helpeth hym to wasten̄ and to souke
Of þat he bribe can̄ or borowe may
Onon̄ he sente his bedde and his araye
Vn to a comper͗e of his own̄ sorte
That loued dise reuell and disporte
And had a wyffe þat held for ꝯcontinance
A schoppe and swived for hir͗e sustenᵃaunce
But her of I will passe as nowe
And of ȝonge gamelyne I will tell ȝowe
¶ The tale of ȝonge gamelyn:
Lithen and listenyth and herkenyth a riȝht
And ȝe schull her of a doghty knyȝht
Sir Iohn of boundes was his name
He couthe of nurtur and of mychel game
Thre sones þe knyght had and with his bodye
The eldest was a myche schrewe and sone be gan
His brethern loued wele hir fader and of hym wer a gaste
The eldest disserued his faders curs and had it at þe laste
The goode knyght his fader lyffed so ȝoor
That deth was cōmyn hym to and handeled hym ful soor
The goode knyȝht cared sor syke þ̉er he laye
Howe his childern schuld liffen aft̉er his daye
He had bene wyde wher but non husbonde he was
All þe londe þat he hadde it was of purchase
Fayn he wold it wer dressed a monge hem alle
That iche of hem had his parte as it myȝht falle
Thoo sente he in to cuntr after wise knyghtes
To helpen to delen his londes and dressen hem to riȝhtes
He sente hem worde by lettres þei schuld hyen blyve
Iff þei wolde speke with hym whils he was on lyffe
div.fw: Tho þe knyghtes herden̄ seke þᵗat he lay
